children.subject:
Haven't taken everything you listed but for those I've taken

CS170: If you wanna do hardware and electronics its best to skip this class and fill in something else. I'm a hardware person myself and I regret taking this class only because I could have filled it with something else I would have enjoyed like 105. I only felt the content up to the second midterm had some relevance but its really theoritical with a small project at the end which is somewhat practical but only worth 5%. 

EECS151: Prolly the class to take if you wanna do digital design. It is also one of the hardest class I've ever taken at Cal since its 5 units. The 2 unit lab which is seperate is a beast of itself, especially the final project. Verilog is a pain in the ass to debug but you learn so much from the labs more than the lectures. This class is the class to take which will immensely help you in recruiting, especially in the fall. Personally, I got recruited from this class alongside 4-5 of my other friends to Apple and other hardware companies (Nvidia, Qualcomm, Citadel, etc) because they all love this class for some reason. When I say recruit I dont mean like career fair recruiting, its actually the company tellin us to drop our resumes in their special form tailored for students in 151. 

EE192: A project based class where the entire semester you work on designing a RC motor car to race in the NATCAR competition. I'd say this class is extremely hard (maybe even more since it's remote rn) since hardware debugging can be super painful and writing embedded systems in C is also a pain in itself to debug. But the project is super interesting and definitely resume worthy since you're combining multiple classes of EECS into 1 big project (parts of 149, 128, 127, 61C). You're basically building this from scratch: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=17qy2T9DwY4&feature=youtu.be&ab_channel=ECEWebAssistant

history.content:
I'm a rising senior in EECS, and there are way too many interesting classes left to take! I'm trying to determine in particular which project-based classes might be the best fit for my interests and potential longer-term career, and which teach me things I can't learn easily once I've left Berkeley.

I'm interested in HCI research, and hope to combine it with either robotics or graphics to create embodied, tangible technologies. I have experience with design and HCI, but less with hardware; I'd like to get experience with hardware and electronics before I graduate so that I'm literate in them for future work.

I anticipate that fall will be heavy on recruiting, research, and grad school applications, so I hesitate to take a heavy course load.

I've taken: EE 120, CS 184, CS 188, EECS 106A, EECS 106B, EE 128, CS 189

I'm considering: CS 170, CS 294-137 (VR), EECS 149, CS 162, CS 287H, EE 105, EE 151, EE 192; I also still need to take either MATH 53 or an upper div math class for a requirement (long story, but I have course equivalency)

Out of these, the three project-based classes I'm thinking might be toughest to fit in (so I can likely only choose 1 or 2 at most): CS 162, EE 151, EE 192

And my current fa21 schedule, which I'm not 100% sure on: CS 170 (maybe swap for 162?), CS 294-137, EECS 149, CYPLAN 140 (or NWMEDIA 262 (Tangible Interfaces) or NWMEDIA 200 (History of New Media))

Thoughts on which (project-based) classes might be the most valuable, and how to craft a reasonable workload while learning and enjoying as much as I can? Many thanks!
history.subject: What project classes should I take in my senior year?
